tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem involving the Von Mises failure criterion. It requires understanding the concept of yield strength and applying it to a biaxial stress state, involving multiple steps to calculate the maximum tensile stress. Since it requires understanding of multiple concepts and has a difficulty score of 6, GPT-5.1 is recommended.

answer_validation.reasoning:
Material follows Von Mises (octahedral shear) yield criterion. Uniaxial yield strength is 200 MPa, so yielding occurs when Von Mises equivalent stress \(\sigma_{e}\) reaches 200 MPa. Plate is under plane stress with \(\sigma_x = 150\,	ext{MPa}\), unknown \(\sigma_y\), and \(	au_{xy}=0\). Principal stresses are simply \(\sigma_1 = \sigma_x\), \(\sigma_2 = \sigma_y\), \(\sigma_3 = 0\). Von Mises equivalent stress for general 3D state is 

\(\sigma_e = \sqrt{	frac{1}{2}[(\sigma_1-\sigma_2)^2 + (\sigma_2-\sigma_3)^2 + (\sigma_3-\sigma_1)^2]}\).

Substituting \(\sigma_1 = 150\), \(\sigma_2 = \sigma_y\), \(\sigma_3 = 0\) and setting \(\sigma_e = 200\) gives: 

\(200^2 = 	frac{1}{2}[(150-\sigma_y)^2 + (\sigma_y-0)^2 + (0-150)^2] = 150^2 - 150\sigma_y + \sigma_y^2.\)

So \(\sigma_y^2 - 150\sigma_y + 22500 - 40000 = 0 \Rightarrow \sigma_y^2 - 150\sigma_y - 17500 = 0.\) Solving the quadratic: \(\sigma_y = \dfrac{150 \pm \sqrt{150^2 + 4\cdot17500}}{2} = \dfrac{150 \pm 303.32}{2}.\) The tensile solution is \(\sigma_y \approx 226.66\,	ext{MPa}\), which rounds to 227 MPa. The compressive root is not relevant because the question asks for maximum uniform tensile stress. Thus option A is correct.

step_by_step: Identify that the material follows the Von Mises (octahedral shear) yield criterion and that yielding starts when the Von Mises equivalent stress equals the uniaxial yield strength 200 MPa.

Recognize the stress state: plane stress with \(\sigma_x = 150\,\text{MPa}\), unknown \(\sigma_y\), and \(\tau_{xy} = 0\). Principal stresses are \(\sigma_1 = 150\,\text{MPa}\), \(\sigma_2 = \sigma_y\), \(\sigma_3 = 0\).
Write the Von Mises equivalent stress in terms of principal stresses: \(\sigma_e = \sqrt{\tfrac{1}{2}[(\sigma_1-\sigma_2)^2 + (\sigma_2-\sigma_3)^2 + (\sigma_3-\sigma_1)^2]}\).
Substitute the principal stresses and set \(\sigma_e = 200\,\text{MPa}\). Square both sides to eliminate the square root and simplify to obtain a quadratic equation in \(\sigma_y\).
Solve the quadratic equation to find two possible values of \(\sigma_y\). Select the positive (tensile) root as the maximum uniform tensile stress along the y-direction before yielding.
Round the computed value (about 226.7 MPa) to the nearest option, giving approximately 227 MPa.

topic.name: Failure theories and yield criteria
topic.syllabus_ref: Structures -> Stress and strain; failure theories (Tresca, Von Mises)

essential: Concept of normal stress and plane stress state
Von Mises yield criterion and equivalent stress
Interpretation of yield strength from uniaxial tension test
helpful: Comparison of Tresca and Von Mises criteria

Main Concept: requires: Understanding of stress components and principal stresses
requires: Knowledge of Von Mises yield criterion for ductile materials
enables: Design of components under multiaxial loading using equivalent stress
enables: Advanced plasticity analysis and yield surfaces in stress space

difficulty_factors: Requires recalling the correct Von Mises formula in terms of principal stresses
Involves algebraic manipulation leading to a quadratic equation
Need to choose the physically meaningful (tensile) root

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.chapter_title: Basic Principles of Stress and Strain
textbook_references.section: Yield criteria and Von Mises criterion

textbook_references.author: Beer and Johnston
textbook_references.section: Theories of Failure for Ductile Materials

video_references.topic_covered: Von Mises yield criterion and distortion energy theory
Von Mises-Hencky theory of failure and equivalent stress

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Identify stress state -> Write Von Mises in principal stresses -> Substitute known stresses -> Form quadratic in unknown stress -> Solve quadratic -> Choose tensile root and match option
key_insights: For plane stress with no shear, the principal stresses are just the normal stresses and zero.
Von Mises criterion converts a biaxial stress state into an equivalent uniaxial stress for comparison with yield strength.
The quadratic equation yields both tensile and compressive possibilities; the question specifically asks for tensile stress.

formulas_principles.name: Von Mises equivalent stress in terms of principal stresses
formulas_principles.conditions: General 3D stress state; used for ductile materials following distortion energy theory
formulas_principles.relevance: Core formula to relate multiaxial stress state to uniaxial yield strength

formulas_principles.name: Yield condition for Von Mises criterion
formulas_principles.conditions: Onset of yielding when equivalent stress equals uniaxial yield strength
formulas_principles.relevance: Defines the boundary of elastic behavior for the material

formulas_principles.name: Quadratic equation for unknown stress
formulas_principles.conditions: Obtained after substituting known stresses and yield strength into Von Mises equation
formulas_principles.relevance: Solving this gives the maximum allowable tensile stress in y-direction

industry_examples: Design of aircraft fuselage skins and pressurized cabin panels subjected to biaxial membrane stresses during flight
Stress analysis of thin-walled pressure vessels and rocket fuel tanks under combined longitudinal and hoop stresses
specific_systems: Aluminum alloy fuselage panels of transport aircraft
Cylindrical propellant tanks in launch vehicles
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Accurate prediction of yielding under multiaxial stress ensures structural components remain within safe elastic limits, preventing permanent deformation, buckling, or catastrophic failure in critical aerospace structures.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using a simple maximum normal stress or Tresca criterion instead of the Von Mises (octahedral shear) criterion specified in the question.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They may memorize only one failure theory or confuse the different criteria under exam pressure.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Underline the specified failure criterion in the question and recall the distinct formulas for Tresca and Von Mises before starting calculations.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to a different allowable stress and an incorrect option choice.

common_mistakes.mistake: Incorrectly writing the Von Mises formula, for example missing the 1/2 factor or omitting one of the stress-difference terms.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Formula is slightly long and symmetric; easy to forget a term or factor.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember that there are three squared differences between principal stresses and a 1/2 factor; quickly check symmetry: (1-2), (2-3), (3-1).
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives wrong equivalent stress and thus wrong allowable \(\sigma_y\).

common_mistakes.mistake: Not recognizing that \(\sigma_3 = 0\) in plane stress and unnecessarily trying to compute principal stresses via Mohr's circle.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Overcomplicating the problem or forgetting that out-of-plane stress is zero in thin plates.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: For thin plates loaded in their plane, set the thickness-direction normal stress to zero unless otherwise stated.
common_mistakes.consequence: Wastes time and increases chance of algebraic errors.

common_mistakes.mistake: Taking the negative root of the quadratic equation as the answer, even though the question asks for maximum tensile stress.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Mechanical solving of quadratic without interpreting the physical meaning of each root.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: After solving, check the sign and physical context: tensile stress must be positive here.
common_mistakes.consequence: Selecting an incorrect option that corresponds to a compressive stress magnitude.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remembering that Von Mises stress uses squared differences of principal stresses with a 1/2 factor inside the square root
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When recalling the general 3D Von Mises formula during exams

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: There are three terms: (1-2), (2-3), (3-1) in the Von Mises expression
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: To avoid omitting any term in the equivalent stress calculation

flashcards.front: Write the Von Mises equivalent stress formula in terms of principal stresses \(\sigma_1, \sigma_2, \sigma_3\).
What condition defines the onset of yielding for a material obeying the Von Mises criterion?
flashcards.back: Yielding begins when the Von Mises equivalent stress equals the uniaxial tensile yield strength: $\sigma_e = \sigma_y$.

flashcards.front: A thin plate has \(\sigma_x = 150\,\text{MPa}\), \(\sigma_y\) unknown, plane stress. How do you set up the Von Mises equation to solve for \(\sigma_y\) if yield strength is 200 MPa?
flashcards.back: Use principal stresses: $\sigma_1 = 150$, $\sigma_2 = \sigma_y$, $\sigma_3 = 0$. Set $200^2 = \tfrac{1}{2}[(150-\sigma_y)^2 + (\sigma_y-0)^2 + (0-150)^2]$ and solve for $\sigma_y$.

flashcards.front: In plane stress, what is the third principal stress and why is it important for Von Mises calculations?
flashcards.back: For a thin plate with no out-of-plane loading, the third principal stress is $\sigma_3 = 0$. It must still be included in the Von Mises expression via terms $(\sigma_2-\sigma_3)$ and $(\sigma_3-\sigma_1)$.

real_world_context.application: Design of aircraft fuselage skin panels under cabin pressurization and aerodynamic loads
real_world_context.industry_example: A fuselage panel may experience hoop stress from internal pressure and longitudinal stress from bending; engineers use Von Mises equivalent stress to ensure combined stresses remain below yield.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Underestimating combined stress can lead to local yielding, permanent deformation, and potential crack initiation, compromising structural integrity and safety.

real_world_context.application: Rocket and satellite propellant tank design
real_world_context.industry_example: Cylindrical tanks have hoop and axial stresses due to internal pressure and acceleration loads; Von Mises criterion is used to size wall thickness and select materials.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Failure of a propellant tank can be catastrophic, leading to mission loss or explosion.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize it as a direct Von Mises application with simple algebra; write the formula in principal stresses, plug numbers, and solve the quadratic. Should take under 3 minutes.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, note that adding tensile stress in y-direction increases equivalent stress; the allowable \(\sigma_y\) must be larger than 150 MPa but not extremely large, so pick the only option significantly above 150 MPa (227 MPa).
exam_strategy.time_management: Limit yourself to about 2â€“3 minutes. If algebra gets messy, quickly re-check the Von Mises formula and the substitution; avoid overcomplicating with Mohr's circle.

search_keywords: Von Mises yield criterion biaxial stress
principal stresses plane stress mechanics of materials

alternative_methods.name: Use stress invariants and J2 formulation
alternative_methods.description: Instead of writing Von Mises in terms of principal stresses, compute the second deviatoric stress invariant J2 from the stress tensor components (\(\sigma_x, \sigma_y, \tau_{xy}\)) and use \(\sigma_e = \sqrt{3J_2}\). For plane stress with zero shear, J2 can be expressed directly in terms of \(\sigma_x\) and \(\sigma_y\).
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Connects to tensor formulation and plasticity theory; scalable to more complex states. Cons: More abstract and algebraically heavier for a simple exam problem.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful in advanced courses on plasticity or finite element analysis where stress invariants are standard.

connections_to_other_subjects.Solid Mechanics: Von Mises criterion is a core topic in strength of materials and plasticity, linking stress analysis to material yielding.
connections_to_other_subjects.Finite Element Methods: FEA post-processing often reports Von Mises stress contours to assess yielding in complex structures.
connections_to_other_subjects.Materials Science: Understanding yield strength, ductility, and stress-strain behavior underpins why Von Mises works well for ductile metals.
connections_to_other_subjects.Aerospace Structures: Design of airframes and spacecraft structures relies on multiaxial failure criteria for sizing and certification.

deeper_dive_topics: Yield surfaces in principal stress space and the Von Mises cylinder
Comparison of Tresca and Von Mises criteria in terms of safety and conservatism
Plastic flow rules and J2 plasticity theory
Effect of hydrostatic stress on yielding and why Von Mises ignores it

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Stress and strain; failure theories for ductile materials
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Question nicely tests direct application of Von Mises criterion under biaxial loading, a core concept in structural design.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided detailed explanations of the Von Mises (distortion energy) criterion, including its formula in terms of principal stresses and applications to multiaxial stress states and torsion. Although not specific to biaxial plate loading, the concepts and formulas were directly applicable. The plate bending chunk was irrelevant and not used.

future_questions_potential: Ask for the maximum compressive stress in y-direction that can be applied with \(\sigma_x = 150\,\text{MPa}\) tension before yielding using Von Mises criterion.
Compare predictions of Tresca and Von Mises criteria for the same biaxial stress state and discuss which is more conservative.
Extend the problem to include a non-zero shear stress \(\tau_{xy}\) and ask for the allowable combination of \(\sigma_y\) and \(\tau_{xy}\).
Provide a Mohr's circle diagram and ask students to extract principal stresses and then apply Von Mises criterion.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: A thin rectangular plate made of isotropic material which satisfies the octahedral (i.e., Von Mises/Distortion energy) failure criterion has yield strength of 200 MPa under uniaxial tension. As shown in the figure, if it is loaded with uniform tension of 150 MPa along the x-direction, the maximum uniform tensile stress that can be applied along the y-direction before the plate starts yielding is about
